data.title: Historical Figures Born on December 22
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays in history for the 22nd of December. See which explorers, inventors and historical figures were born on December 22.
data.text:
Diocletian

Roman Emperor (284-305) who defeated the Sarmatians and Carpi [born between 242 and 245], born in Salona, Dalmatia, Roman Empire

Roger II

Count of Sicily (1105-30) and later King of Sicily (1130-54), born in Mileto, Calabria

Emperor Antoku of Japan, born in Kyoto, Kyoto Prefecture, Japan (d. 1185)

Luca della Robbia, Italian sculptor (Madonna of Rose Garden), born in Florence (d. 1482)

Sultan Cem, third son of Sultan Mehmed II and pretender to the Ottoman throne, born in Rumelia, Ottoman Empire (d. 1495)

Mary of Guise [Mary of Lorraine], French Queen consort of Scots (1538-42) and Regent of Scotland for daughter Mary Queen of Scots (1554-60), born in Bar-le-Duc, France (d. 1560)

Kuroda Yoshitaka, Japanese daimyō, born in Himeji, Hyōgo Prefecture, Japan (d. 1604)

Cesare Cremonini, Italian professor of natural philosophy, born in Cento, Papal States (now Italy) (d. 1631)

Ernst Casimir I, count of Nassau-Dietz and Stadtholder of Friesland, Groningen, and Drenthe, born in Dillenburg, Germany (d. 1632)

Jean Racine

French dramatist (Phèdre, Athalie), born in La Ferté-Milon, Picardy

Johann J Dillenius [Dillen], German botanist (Historia Muscorum), born in Darmstadt, Landgraviate of Hesse-Darmstadt, Holy Roman Empire (d. 1747)

Meidingnu Pamheiba, King of Manipur, born in Manipur (d. 1751)

Hermann Samuel Reimarus, German philosopher and writer, born in Hamburg, Germany (d. 1768)

James Oglethorpe, British soldier, politician, philanthropist, and founder of the US colony of Georgia, born in Godalming, Surrey, England (d. 1758)

Egbert de Vrij Temminck, Amsterdam regent, born in Amsterdam (d. 1785)

Jean-Étienne Liotard, Swiss-French painter, art connoisseur, and dealer (Madame d'Epinay), born in Geneva, Switzerland (d. 1789)

William Ellery, US attorney and signer of the Declaration of Independence (Rhode Island), born in Newport, Rhode Island (d. 1820)

Charles Frederick, Margrave, Elector and later Grand Duke of Baden, born in Baden-Württemberg, Germany (d. 1811)

Johann Friedrich Pfaff, German mathematician, born in Stuttgart, Germany (d. 1825)

John Crome (Old Crome), English landscape artist, born in Norwich, England (d. 1821)

Alexander Gordon Laing, Scottish explorer (1st European to reach Timbuktu), born in Edinburgh, Scotland (d. 1826)

Thomas Ainsworth, English founder of Nijverdal & industrialist (Twentse textile), born in Lancashire, England (d. 1841)

Joseph King Fenno Mansfield, American Major General (Union Army), born in New Haven, Connecticut (d. 1862)

John Obadiah Westwood, British entomologist, born in Sheffield, United Kingdom (d. 1893)

Johann Sebastian Welhaven, Norwegian poet, born in Bergen, Norway (d. 1873)

Johann Jakob Bachofen, Swiss antiquarian & jurist, born in Basel, Switzerland (d. 1887)

Pierre Ossian Bonnet, French mathematician, born in Montpellier, France (d. 1892)

James Scott Negley, American politician and Major General (Union Army), born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (d. 1901)

Justin M'Carthy, Irish politician and novelist (Miss Misanthrope), born in Cork, Ireland (d. 1912)

Mark Rutherford [Hale White], English writer, born in Bedford, England (d. 1913)

1831 Robert Ogden Tyler, Bvt Major General (Union Army), born in Hunter, New York (d. 1874)

Edward Hatch, American Brevet Major General (Union Army), born in Bangor, Maine (d. 1889)

Constantin Fahlberg, Russian chemist who discovered Saccharin (artificial sweetener), born in Tambov, Russia (d. 1910) [1]

Yevgraf Fyodorov, Russian mathematician, born in Orensburg, Russia (d. 1919)

Frank Kellogg

American politician and diplomat (US Secretary of State, 1925-29), tried to outlaw war (Kellogg–Briand Pact: Nobel Peace Prize, 1929), born in Potsdam, New York

Austin Norman Palmer, American penmanship innovator, born in Fort Jackson, New York (d. 1927)

Erich Schaeder, German theologist (Theocentric Theology), born in Clausthal, Germany (d. 1936)

Jean-Baptiste Marchand, French military officer and explorer in Africa, born in Thoissey, France (d. 1934)

František Xaver Šalda, Czechoslovakian literary critic, born in Liberec, Czech Republic (d. 1937)

1867 Joseph Maria Olbrich, Austrian architect (Wiener Sezession), born in Opava, Czech Republic (d. 1908)

1867 Wilhelm Groener, German soldier and politician, born in Ludwigsburg, Germany (d. 1939)

Dmitri Egorov, Russian-Soviet mathematician, born in Moscow, Russia (d. 1931)

1869 Edwin Arlington Robinson, American poet (Richard Corey), born in Head Tide, Maine (d. 1935)

Camille Guérin, French veterinarian and bacteriologist, born in Poitiers, France (d. 1961)

Filippo Tommaso Marinetti, Italian-French prose writer, novelist, poet, and dramatist (Futurism e Futurista), born in Alexandria, Egypt (d. 1944)

Stephen Timoshenko [Stepan Tymoshenko], Ukrainian-American mechanical engineer (elasticity; strength of materials), and pedagogue, born in Shpotovka, Russian Empire (d. 1972)

Stanislas Bizot, French draughts champion (1925), born in Nice, France (d. 1950)

Enver Pasa, Turkish politician, born in Istanbul, Turkey (d. 1922)

Arthur James Cook, British trade union leader (coal miners), born in Wookey, Somerset (d. 1931)

Srinivasa Ramanujan, Indian mathematician (number theory), born in Erode, British India (d. 1920)

J. Arthur Rank, English industrialist, born in Kingston upon Hull, United Kingdom (d. 1972)

Mikha`il Na'imah, Lebanese playwright, born in Baskinta, Lebanon (d. 1988)

Harry Pollitt, General Secretary of the Communist Party of Great Britain, born in Droylsden, United Kingdom (d. 1960)

1890 Mark Tobey, American abstract painter (Broadway Norm), born in Centerville, Wisconsin (d. 1976)

Nikolay Semyonovich Tikhonov, Russian poet and writer, born in St Petersburg, Russia (d. 1979)

Lionel Charles Robbins, British economist, born in Middlesex, England (d. 1984)

1898 Vladimir Aleksandrovich Fock, Soviet physicist, born in Saint Petersburg, Russia (d. 1974)

Joe Adonis, Italian American crime-syndicate boss in NY & NJ, born in Montemarano, Italy (d. 1971)

1902 Philippe Leclerc de Hauteclocque, French general and WWII hero known as the "Liberator of Paris", born in Belloy-Saint-Léonard, France (d. 1947)

Barbara Moore, Russian-born British engineer (walked across US in 86 days in 1960), born in Russia (d. 1977)

Haldan Keffer Hartline

American biophysicist (Nobel 1967), born in Bloomsburg, Pennsylvania

Louis-Eugene-Felix Neel, French physicist (Nobel 1970), born in Lyon, France (d. 2000)

Kenneth Rexroth, American poet and translator & critical essayist (Birds in the Bush), born in South Bend, Indiana (d. 1982)

Tommy Flowers

English engineer (Colossus), born in Poplar, London

Marius Duintjer, Dutch architect (Kolenkit), born in Veendam, Netherlands (d. 1983)

1908 Max Bill, Swiss architect and artist (Ruban Sans Fin), born in Winterthur, Switzerland (d. 1994)

Grote Reber, American radio astronomer (1st parabolic radio telescope), born in Wheaton, Illinois (d. 2002)

Claudia A. "Lady Bird" Taylor Johnson, American first lady (1963-1969), born in Karnack, Texas (d. 2007)

Anthony Barber Doncaster, English bookseller, born in Sheffield, England (d. 1995)

Andrew Fielding Huxley, English physiologist (Nobel 1963), born in London, England (d. 2012)

1917 Piet De Somer, Belgian physician and biologist (U of Leuven), born in Belgium (d. 1985)

Calder Willingham, American novelist and scriptwriter, born in Atlanta, Georgia (d. 1995)

1922 Jack Brooks, American politician, born in Crowley, Louisiana (d. 2012)

1922 Jim Wright, American Democratic politician and Speaker of the House (1987-89), born in Forth Worth, Texas (d. 2015)

Joseph Muhler, American biochemist and dentist (developed Crest - 1st fluoride toothpaste), born in Fort Wayne, Indiana (d. 1996) [1]

Lewis Glucksman, American financier, born in Manhattan, New York (d. 2006)

Lee Salk, Russian-American child psychologist and author, born in New York, New York (d. 1992)

Larry Stevenson [Richard], American skateboard innovator (kicktail), born in Santa Monica, California (d. 2012)

John L. Finley, United States Navy aviator, born in Winchester, Massachusetts (d. 2006)

Lucien Bouchard, French Canadian lawyer and politician, born in Saint-Cœur-de-Marie, Quebec

Paul Wolfowitz, American political scientist and diplomat, born in Brooklyn, New York

Joris J. C. Voorhoeve, Dutch Defense minister (1994-, VVD), born in the Hague, Netherlands

Pamela Courson, American woman and long-term companion of Jim Morrison, born in Weed, California (d. 1974)

Brian C. Daley, American sci-fi author (Exploits of Han Solo, Tron), born in Englewood, New Jersey

Ray Guy, American College-Pro Football HOF punter (Southern Miss; Super Bowl 1976, 80, 84; 6 × First-team All-Pro; 7 × Pro Bowl; Oakland/LA Raiders), born in Swainsboro, Georgia (d. 2022)

Charles de Lint, Canadian sci-fi author (Moonhear, Mulengro, Yarrow), born in Bussum, Netherlands

1951 Gerald Cavendish Grosvenor, 6th Duke of Westminster, British peer and its 3rd richest person, born in Omagh, Northern Ireland (d. 2016)

Jayaseelan Naidoo, South African worker's union leader, born in Durban, South Africa

Carole James, Canadian politician, born in Dukinfield, United Kingdom

1957 Susan Powter, Australian-born American motivational speaker, nutritionist, personal trainer, and author (The Susan Powter Show), born in Sydney, Australia

Jean-Michel Basquiat, American artist (Gray, SAMO), born in Brooklyn, NYC, New York (d. 1988)

1960 Patrick Fitzgerald, American lawyer, born in New York City

Andrew Fastow, US convicted criminal and businessman (former CFO of Enron), born in Washington, D.C., United States

1961 Yuri Ivanovich Malinchenko, Russian cosmonaut (1st person to marry in space), born in Khrushchev, Ukrainian SSR, USSR

Luna H. Mitani, Japanese-American surrealist painter, born in Hokkaido, Japan

Ted Cruz

Canadian-born US politician (Senate-R-Texas 2013-), born in Calgary. Alberta

Chris Adler, American writer, born in Cheverly, Maryland
